top_comment.text:
Although I accept that TYT is probably mostly correct, that the reason for 
the "fine" is based on pro-fossil fuel lobby efforts...  *But*, they didn't 
even try to discuss what the argument used for why there could be a fine.  
They just act like it is an obvious fact that electric companies should 
have to buy your excess electricity.  Guess what?  That just isn't how the 
grid works.  I'm not an expert, but, I do work (somewhat) in the industry.  
And, I do know that balancing power on the electric grid is nontrivial. And 
electric companies are not always able to use your excess electricity.

The electric industry does not have huge banks of batteries or capacitors 
to store electricity.  Thus, if more electricity is produced than there are 
users of electricity, it goes to waste.  Electric companies bring up or 
shut down generators to match supply and demand.  But, they aren't in 
control of the electric you may happen to have extra and want to sell to 
them. Thus making it much more difficult for the electric company to 
balance generation vs usage when they don't control the generation!

By the way, I am very liberal.  And I support green energy and all that 
rot.  I don't want anybody saying I'm some FOX stoolie.  No, I'm a 
programmer whose software is used in the electric industry.

In this particular story, by not even attempting to discuss the issues at 
hand as to why there could be issues with selling excess electricity to the 
electric company makes the journalism here as bad as FOX.﻿

comments.text:
+soylentgreenb How is that not true, when you say that the peak load occurs 
2-5 pm in the summer, when the sun is still high in the sky? Peak demand 
does vary in different places and different seasons. It is higher during 
the day and will peak in late afternoon to early evening. According 
to FERC, it is earlier than 7pm for every region of the US. In the summer, 
that is still daylight.

Since you mentioned Europe, Germany generates 50% of its peak summer demand 
from solar even though it has fewer sunny days than the US.
comments.author: Eric14492

comments.text:
+Eric14492 That's not even true in California, where peak load occurs at 
2-5 PM in the dead of summer and 7-10 PM from august to april. Even in 
summer the evening peak is a substantial bump.

In places like Europe or substantial parts of the US, peak load is always 
in the evenings, and demand is higher in the middle of winter, which 
coincides with hydro producing very little electricity in places where we 
have this thing called snow and ice.
comments.author: soylentgreenb

comments.text:
Solar power generation not only saves individuals money, it also saves 
electrical utilities money. Utilities need capacity for their peak load. 
This is on hot sunny days when everyone's AC is on. This is also when solar 
panels generate the most power. By not only reducing peak demand, but also 
supplying additional power at those times, utilities avoid having to 
building new power plants as usage increases. The only people who lose are 
the oil and gas suppliers.

This doesn't even include the costs of global warming, which are 
astronomic. Government should be doing everything possible to move us away 
from carbon based energy sources. Instead of charging fees, the government 
should subsidized renewable energy. It should also eliminate the huge 
subsidies that oil and coal receive.

General demand increases over time. What they are trying to do is to not

that they can cycle off your compressor during this time...to control peak 
demand. They give you a monthly cash bonus for this.
I'm negating my own AC power demand at that time - using hardware I paid 
$$$ for - without any compensation. And I still pay the same 
grid-connection fee that all customers pay monthly. My argument is: I buy

I save them money by adding peak-demand power - at my own cost...I

When you have utility integrated system your house isn't using the power 
the panels generate per say. The breaker in a solar system is called a 
"backfeed breaker" and you're sending all the power back to the grid. Most 
people are gone working during the day and all the power is fed back. When 
the sun goes down, you come home, you turn stuff on and start drawing from 
the utility company. Generally, in the U.S., it doesn't makes sense to 
oversize your system b/c the payback isn't that significant to offset the 
cost of the system. Other countries have great feed in tariff programs 
where it totally makes sense to oversize.

The slam campaign the Koch bros funded in AZ wouldn't be laughable if I 
didn't work for one of the companies they were slamming. They were trying 
to compare the company that I work for to Solyndra. Solyndra was an epic 
cluster fuck but they were a panel manufacturer in a technology that 
doesn't even exist anymore as far as i know. The company that I work for is 
an integrator, meaning we take the components of the system from 
manufacturers and then install it on the customers home. And we never took 
a dime from the stimulus like Solyndra did. I'm glad people saw through 
some of the bullshit in AZ.

comments.text:
Since the power going into you home is alternating current, it can go back 
to the power company as easily as it goes into your home. The excess is 
credited to you for times when you use more than you produce.
comments.author: nsecchi1

comments.text:
The meter runs both ways. You can't go off grid without a battery. But you 
can still save a bundle because you produce power when the sun shines, and 
you can use it all, but if you don't, it just goes to keeping pressure up 
on your local tiny end section of the grid.  You only get charged for the 
*net* amount of energy you used over the month versus the amount of energy 
you produced during the month.  Your neighbors use the extra solar energy 
from your house that you don't.  It saves the utility from turning on 
special peak generators in the hot afternoon, and it also eats into their 
bottom line because the peak rate is the highest.  It's good news for 
everyone, but bad news for the state-supported monopoly power utility's 
bottom line.  They should accept their reduced stature and change their 
business model, not try to destroy solar before it destroys them.
comments.author: Bryan Seigneur

little by little so it weans people off solar.
Biodiesel for your cars can be made in your garage from kitchen scraps and 
old grease, but who wants to have a chemistry set and a production plant in 
their yard when there'll be biofuel stations selling at gasoline prices or 
higher?
Wind is ok if you're in the right area, but aside from massive corporate 
owned windfarms, its not a practical source countrywide, maybe as a backup 
or secondary source locally.
Hydroelectric we've had for a long time, and it goes without saying that's 
not something you can do personally.
Geothermal, I don't know, if that ever becomes practical for home use, 
it'll be an innovation out of Iceland because they use that a lot.
But solar.... solar, I don't know.  it's come a long way, and it's only 
going to get better and cheaper as the tech improves, the key is 
distribution.  If everyone had like a bit of their roof dedicated to solar, 
that'd kill Oil as we know it, or at least diminish it.  But they're going 
to do everything in their power to keep it expensive.  Though I've been 
reading good things about that shingle or paint like solar panel that still 
works pretty good for pennies on the dollar that doesn't even look like 
traditional panels.  If they can get that down, it seems inevitable it's 
going to get widely distributed, no matter what.
The key to killing stuff like this is to stop it while its still in its 
infancy, so it can't advance to the point where it becomes a no brainer in 
the marketplace.
I mean, the early car was no competition for horse drawn carriages until it 
got refined over the years to where it could outcompete carriages in the 
marketplace, and I'm sure there were naysayers back then that said the car 
would never replace the carriage.
The longer solar remains viable economically, the more likely it is to 
become the next core energy source.
Koch just isn't smart for not getting into this, scumbag tactics 
notwithstanding.
